title: On the Ruin of Britain [De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae]
description:
De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae is a 6th-century sermon and history of Britain attributed to St. Gildas. De Excidio, or On the Ruin of Britain, is greatly valued by historians and scholars as one of the very few surviving sources of Britain in the 5th- and 6th-centuries.

This digital edition (2014) by T. Habington is based on the 1842 English translation by J. A. Giles.

The text of De Excidio contains the first reference to Ambrosius Aurelianus, a Romano-British war-leader often identified as the inspiration for the "historical King Arthur."
creator: Gildas; Giles, J.A.; Habington, T.
subject: Great Britain; History; Kings; Ambrosius Aurelianus; Roman Britain

title: On the Ruin of Britain, Chapter 1 [De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae],
description:
De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae is a 6th-century sermon and history of Britain attributed to St. Gildas. De Excidio, or On the Ruin of Britain, is greatly valued by historians and scholars as one of the very few surviving sources of Britain in the 5th- and 6th-centuries.

This digital audio edition (2022) by Carol Pelster is based on the 1842 English translation by J. A. Giles.

The text of De Excidio contains the first reference to Ambrosius Aurelianus, a Romano-British war-leader often identified as the inspiration for the "historical King Arthur."

Chapter 1 focuses on the history of Britain from its conquest by Rome until Gildas' time.
creator: Gildas; Giles, J.A.; Pelster, Carol;
subject: Great Britain; History; Kings; Ambrosius Aurelianus; Roman Britain

title: On the Ruin of Britain, Chapter 2 [De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae]
description:
De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae is a 6th-century sermon and history of Britain attributed to St. Gildas. De Excidio, or On the Ruin of Britain, is greatly valued by historians and scholars as one of the very few surviving sources of Britain in the 5th- and 6th-centuries.

This digital audio edition (2022) by Carol Pelster is based on the 1842 English translation by J. A. Giles.

The text of De Excidio contains the first reference to Ambrosius Aurelianus, a Romano-British war-leader often identified as the inspiration for the "historical King Arthur."

In the second part, here referred to as Chapter 2, Gildas excoriates five historical British kings, with frequent allegorical references to the apocalyptic Book of Daniel and Book of Revelation.
creator: Gildas; Giles, J.A.; Pelster, Carol;
subject: Great Britain; History; Kings; Ambrosius Aurelianus; Roman Britain

title: On the Ruin of Britain, Chapter 3 [De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae]
description:
De Excidio et Conquestu Britanniae is a 6th-century sermon and history of Britain attributed to St. Gildas. De Excidio, or On the Ruin of Britain, is greatly valued by historians and scholars as one of the very few surviving sources of Britain in the 5th- and 6th-centuries.

This digital audio edition (2022) by Carol Pelster is based on the 1842 English translation by J. A. Giles.

The text of De Excidio contains the first reference to Ambrosius Aurelianus, a Romano-British war-leader often identified as the inspiration for the "historical King Arthur."

In the third part, Chapter 3, Gildas expands his attention to the priests and clergy of his own time.

title: History of the Britons [Historia Brittonum]
description:
Written in the first quarter of the 9th century, Historia Brittonum, or The History of the Britons, is a historical chronical of the native peoples of the British Isles (the Britons) attributed to the Welsh monk Nennius. The text begins with the settlement of Britan by the Trojan Brutus and situates a British historical tradition within the classical epic literature of the Greeks (the Iliad and the Odyssey) and Romans (the ). Among the chronology of kings, a Life of St. Patrick, and other tales both historical and fantastic, the story of King Arthur appears for the first time.

In the Historia Brittonum King Arthur appears as a "dux bellorum" (commander of a Roman expeditionary force), and not "rex" (king), and the narrative details a series of twelve battles fought by Arthur and other kings of Britain against Saxon tribes.

The text of this audio recording is based on the 1847 English translation by J.A. Giles, and recorded by BUAES and Amy Gramour in 2010.
creator: Nennius; Giles, J.A.; BUAES; Amy Gramour
subject: Great Britain; History; Kings; King Arthur; Wales;

title: King Arthur, from the Heroes Tapestries
description:
A close-up of King Arthur from the Heroes Tapestries held by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, NY.

This piece is one of a group of tapestries that feature the Nine Heroes, a medieval motif celebrating three men from each of the following traditions: Classical (Hector of Troy, Alexander the Great, Julius Caesar); Jewish (Joshua, David, Judas Maccabeus); and Christian (King Arthur, Charlemagne, Godfrey of Bouillon). These men, considered to be the pillars of chivalry, justice, and nobility, inspired numerous pieces of literature and art.

The Met's collection, displayed at The Cloisters, is dated to between 1400 and 1410, and while only five of the original heroes are held by the museum, scholars believe it once featured all nine of the traditional heroes.
creator: Unknown
subject: King Arthur; Tapestry; Art;

title: La mort d'Arthur
description:
This painting by James Archer (1823-1904) visualizes the death of King Arthur after the Battle of Camlann. In the painting, Arthur is attended to by four women, one of whom is Guinevere, his queen. In the background on the left, Merlin and Nimue can be seen along the shore of a body of water, while on the right a ship awaits and a ghostly spirit holds the Holy Grail.

The oil painting, completed in 1860, was acquired by the Manchester Art Gallery in 1952, a generous gift from L. A. Haworth. It belongs to a series of Arthurian-inspired paintings done by Archer beginning around 1859, all heavily influenced by the art and literature of the Romantics and Victorians.
creator: Archer, James
subject: King Arthur; Art;
